user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>

Another agent reported that the target code violated the Rule 8.13.
Here is the comment from the agent.
<violation scenario>
The pointer 'module' is declared as OS_module_internal_record_t * but in the shown fragment it is only used for read access (module->flags). Per MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 the pointer should be const-qualified when possible (e.g. const OS_module_internal_record_t *module). Therefore this use (if ((module->flags & OS_MODULE_FLAG_LOCAL_SYMBOLS) != 0)) constitutes a violation — 'module' could and should be declared pointing to a const-qualified type.
</violation scenario>

Your job is to insert logging code to capture the control flow and state information of the program.
Insert logging code so that other agents can reproduce and get evidence for the violation scenario.
<response format>
- test_code: a modified OS_ModuleLoad_Impl code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/43.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If test code is not required to validate the scenario, you can leave this blank.
Here are the constraints for the test code:
- The test code MUST preserve the original logic of OS_ModuleLoad_Impl as much as possible.
You CAN just insert probe functions to the original code.
- DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
- The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
- The test code MUST include line breaks.
- You MUST NOT define the main function.
- You MUST NOT define macros.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleLoad_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleLoad_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const char *translated_path)
{
    int32                             status = OS_ERROR;
    int                               dl_mode;
    OS_impl_module_internal_record_t *impl;
    OS_module_internal_record_t *     module;

    impl   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_module_table, *token);
    module = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_module_table, *token);

    /*
     * RTLD_NOW should instruct dlopen() to resolve all the symbols in the
     * module immediately, as opposed to waiting until they are used.
     * The latter (lazy mode) is non-deterministic - a resolution error on
     * a rarely-used symbol could cause a random failure far in the future.
     */
    dl_mode = RTLD_NOW;

    if ((module->flags & OS_MODULE_FLAG_LOCAL_SYMBOLS) != 0)
    {
        /*
         * Do not add the symbols in this module to the global symbol table.
         * This mode helps prevent any unanticipated references into this
         * module, which can in turn prevent unloading via dlclose().
         */
        dl_mode |= RTLD_LOCAL;
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * Default mode - add symbols to the global symbol table, so they
         * will be available to resolve symbols in future module loads.
         * However, any such references will prevent unloading of this
         * module via dlclose().
         */
        dl_mode |= RTLD_GLOBAL;
    }

    dlerror();
    impl->dl_handle = dlopen(translated_path, dl_mode);
    if (impl->dl_handle != NULL)
    {
        status = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error loading shared library: %s\n", dlerror());
    }

    return status;
}
```
</target_code>
Please provide the modified OS_ModuleLoad_Impl code.
